information_requirement: Is an adversary manipulating the I/O image of a PLC to inhibit its response function?

evidence.description: Modbus Function Code 5 (Force Single Coil) or 15 (Force Multiple Coils) commands observed in Zeek modbus.log where the source IP (id.orig_h) is not listed in the authorized Engineering Workstation (EWS) IP allowlist, OR the originating process on the EWS (from Windows Event ID 4688) is not an approved engineering application (e.g., 'Studio5000.exe', 'TIA_Portal.exe'), OR the command timestamp (ts) falls outside pre-defined operational or maintenance windows for the targeted PLC.
evidence.nai: Industrial Demilitarized Zone (IDMZ) network segments, Control Network segments (Level 3.5 and 3 of Purdue Model), Process Control Network (PCN) segments (Level 2 of Purdue Model), Engineering Workstation (EWS) endpoints, PLC network interfaces.
evidence.action:
1. Symbolic Logic Detection: Filter Zeek modbus.log for function_code:5 or function_code:15. For each command, perform the following checks: A. Compare id.orig_h (source IP) against a centrally managed allowlist of authorized EWS IPs. If the source IP is not in the allowlist, generate a high-priority alert. B. If the source IP is authorized, correlate id.orig_h from Zeek modbus.log with ComputerName from Zeek conn.log and ProcessName from Windows Event ID 4688 (process creation) on the originating EWS within a 5-minute window. Compare this ProcessName against a strict allowlist of approved engineering software (e.g., 'Studio5000.exe', 'TIA_Portal.exe'). If the process is not on the allowlist, generate an alert. C. Check if the ts (timestamp) of the Modbus command falls outside pre-approved operational windows (e.g., 07:00-17:00 M-F) or scheduled maintenance periods for the targeted PLC. If any of these conditions (A, B, or C) are met, generate a high-priority alert detailing the source IP, target PLC IP, Modbus function code, originating process (if available), and timestamp. 
2. Statistical Anomaly Detection: For each unique (target PLC IP, source EWS IP) pair, establish a 30-day rolling baseline for the hourly frequency of Modbus Function Code 5 and 15 commands. Calculate the 99th percentile of this hourly frequency. Alert if the current hourly count for any pair exceeds its 99th percentile, indicating an unusual surge in force commands. Additionally, track the mean and standard deviation of the ts (timestamp) for these commands, aggregated by (target PLC IP, source EWS IP) and day of week. Alert if a command's timestamp falls outside the mean +/- 3 standard deviations for that specific PLC, EWS, and day of week, indicating an unusual time of execution. 
3. Machine Learning Classification: Utilize a deployed supervised machine learning model (e.g., Random Forest or XGBoost), trained on historical Zeek modbus.log data for Function Codes 5 and 15, to classify real-time Modbus commands. Ensure the model uses features such as id.orig_h (source IP), id.resp_h (destination IP), function_code, coil_address, coil_value, ts (hour of day, day of week), and ProcessName from correlated Windows Event ID 4688 data. Generate a high-confidence alert if a command is classified as 'anomalous' with a prediction probability exceeding 0.9, indicating a potential manipulation of the I/O image.

evidence.description: Modbus Function Code 6 (Preset Single Register) or 16 (Preset Multiple Registers) commands observed in Zeek modbus.log where the source IP (id.orig_h) is not listed in the authorized Engineering Workstation (EWS) IP allowlist, OR the originating process on the EWS (from Windows Event ID 4688) is not an approved engineering application, OR the 'register_value' in the command falls outside of pre-defined safe operational ranges for the targeted register (e.g., a temperature setpoint exceeding critical limits, a valve position outside normal operational bounds).
evidence.nai: Process Control Network (PCN) segments (Level 2 of Purdue Model), critical PLC backplanes, Engineering Workstation (EWS) endpoints, PLC network interfaces.
evidence.action:
1. Symbolic Logic Detection: Filter Zeek modbus.log for function_code:6 or function_code:16. For each command, perform the following checks: A. Verify if id.orig_h (source IP) is on a centrally managed allowlist of authorized EWS IPs. If not, generate an immediate high-priority alert. B. If the source IP is authorized, correlate id.orig_h from Zeek modbus.log with ComputerName from Zeek conn.log and ProcessName from Windows Event ID 4688 (process creation) on the corresponding EWS within a 5-minute window. Verify ProcessName against a strict allowlist of approved engineering applications. If an unauthorized process is identified, generate an alert. C. For known critical I/O image registers, check if the register_address and register_value in the Modbus command fall outside pre-defined safe operational ranges for the targeted PLC (e.g., a temperature setpoint exceeding critical limits). If so, generate an alert. If any of these conditions (A, B, or C) are met, generate a high-priority alert detailing the source IP, target PLC IP, Modbus function code, register address, register value, and originating process (if available). 
2. Statistical Anomaly Detection: For each target PLC, establish a 30-day rolling baseline for the hourly frequency of Modbus Function Code 6 and 16 commands. Calculate the 99th percentile of this hourly frequency. Alert if the current hourly count for any PLC exceeds its 99th percentile, indicating an unusual surge in write commands. Additionally, monitor the register_value for critical I/O image registers. Calculate the historical mean and standard deviation of these values over the last 30 days. Alert if a newly written register_value for a critical register deviates by more than 3 standard deviations from its historical mean, indicating an anomalous manipulation of a critical process parameter. 
3. Machine Learning Anomaly Detection: Utilize a deployed unsupervised anomaly detection model (e.g., Isolation Forest or One-Class SVM), trained on several months of historical 'normal' Modbus write activity, to analyze real-time Modbus commands. Ensure the model uses features extracted from Zeek modbus.log for Function Codes 6 and 16, including id.orig_h, id.resp_h, function_code, register_address, register_value, data_length, and ts (hour of day, day of week). Calculate an anomaly score for each command and generate an alert if the anomaly score exceeds the 95th percentile of historical anomaly scores, indicating a potentially malicious or highly unusual write operation.
